title: Anthropic adds Allianz to growing list of enterprise wins
description: Anthropic announces its first enterprise deal of 2026 with Munich-based global insurance conglomerate Allianz. The partnership includes three initiatives: 1) Making Claude Code available to all Allianz employees, 2) Building custom AI agents for multistep workflows with human in the loop, 3) An AI system that logs all AI interactions for transparency and regulatory compliance. According to a December survey from Anthropic investor Menlo Ventures, Anthropic holds 40% of enterprise AI market share and 54% for AI coding, up from 32% in July. Recent enterprise deals include Snowflake ($200M), Accenture, Deloitte (500K employees), and IBM.
author: Rebecca Szkutak

title: Developers Are Solving the Wrong Problem
description: Hacker News discussion about AI/LLM acting as an interface between developers and efficient machine coding, exploring how developers should adapt to AI coding tools.
author: Hacker News Community

title: LMArena lands $1.7B valuation four months after launching its product
description: LMArena, a startup that began as a UC Berkeley research project (Chatbot Arena) in 2023, raised $150M Series A at $1.7B valuation led by Felicis and UC Investments. The company previously raised $100M seed in May 2025 at $600M valuation. LMArena provides crowdsourced AI model performance leaderboards through its consumer website where users compare model outputs. The platform has 5M monthly users across 150 countries with 60M conversations/month. In September 2025, it launched commercial AI Evaluations service for enterprises, model labs, and developers, achieving $30M annualized consumption rate (ARR) as of December. Participating VC firms include Andreessen Horowitz, Kleiner Perkins, Lightspeed, and others.
author: Julie Bort

title: AI coding assistants are getting worse?
description: Hacker News discussion about the non-repeatable nature of AI coding assistant results and whether they're actually improving or declining in quality.
author: Hacker News Community

title: LLM predictions for 2026, shared with Oxide and Friends
description: Simon Willison shares his 1, 3, and 6-year predictions for AI and coding agents. Key insights: 1) It will become undeniable that LLMs write good code in 2026, 2) We'll finally solve sandboxing, 3) A 'Challenger disaster' for coding agent security is coming, 4) Coding agents Jevons paradox will resolve in 3 years, 5) Someone will build a new browser using mainly AI-assisted coding, 6) In 6 years, typing code by hand will go the way of punch cards. He notes that reasoning models trained with RL in 2025 dramatically improved code quality, with Claude Opus 4.5 and GPT-5.2 reducing hand-written code to single-digit percentages.
author: Simon Willison

title: In 2026, AI will move from hype to pragmatism
description: Comprehensive TechCrunch analysis on AI trends for 2026. Key themes: 1) Shift from scaling laws to new architectures - experts believe transformer scaling is plateauing, 2) Rise of Small Language Models (SLMs) - fine-tuned SLMs will match larger models in accuracy for enterprise applications while being more cost-effective, 3) World Models emerging - AI systems that learn 3D spatial reasoning, with applications in gaming ($276B market by 2030), 4) Agentic workflows becoming practical with Model Context Protocol (MCP) becoming the 'USB-C for AI' - adopted by OpenAI, Microsoft, and donated to Linux Foundation, 5) 2026 as 'year of the humans' - focus on augmentation not automation, 6) Physical AI going mainstream with wearables, robotics, AVs, and drones.
author: Rebecca Bellan

title: He was called a 'terrorist sympathizer.' Now his AI company is valued at $3B
description: Profile of Replit founder Amjad Masad discussing the company's $3 billion valuation and addressing past controversies. The article explores Masad's journey and Replit's position in the AI coding space.
author: San Francisco Standard

title: My LLM coding workflow going into 2026
description: Addy Osmani shares his comprehensive AI coding workflow for 2026. Key principles: 1) Start with clear specs before coding - 'waterfall in 15 minutes', 2) Break work into small iterative chunks, 3) Provide extensive context and guidance to LLMs, 4) Choose the right model for each task, 5) Leverage AI across the SDLC including CLI tools like Claude Code and async agents like Jules, 6) Keep human in the loop - verify, test, and review everything, 7) Commit often and use version control as safety net, 8) Customize AI behavior with rules and examples (CLAUDE.md files), 9) Embrace testing and automation as force multipliers, 10) Continuously learn and adapt. Notable: ~90% of Claude Code is now written by Claude Code itself.
author: Addy Osmani
